data.title: Sam Shepard on "Cold in July"
data.meta_description: Every January the slopes of Park City, Utah, fill with posh skiers, and the streets, bars, and screening rooms fill with Hollywood’s top actors, producers, and directors. Vanity Fair West Coast senior editor Krista Smith sat down to talk with the stars of the Sundance Film Festival, and learned all about the movies that will thrill us in 2014.
data.text:
It's an absolute thrill for me, personally,

to sit and talk with you.

Oh, thank you.

I could talk about a million...

Your writings, your movies, and, obviously

you're here for Cold in July, which is

a great, fun ride, where you don't know

where it's going at any turn,

even in the end.

Yeah.

I don't know where I was, and I kind of just

wanted to see more of it.

So, it's excellent.

And I remember seeing here,

a couple of years ago, Mud.

Oh, yeah.

Yeah. What about McConaughey? Huh? How do you

feel about that?

Well, he's getting better and better.

Yeah, I'd say he's kind of having a McConaughssaince.

(laughing)

It's really great to see an actor find himself, you know.

In his sojourn, you know.

Have you seen Dallas Buyer's Club?

No, I haven't, but I can imagine.

Yeah. That's great he's getting all kinds

of accolades.

Yeah.

For you, what is it that makes you gravitate

towards the parts that you do.

I mean, recently, I, obviously saw you in Mud,

and then you were in Osage County,

and you're in this one.

What is it that kind of drags you out of your house

and makes you want to do a role?

Well, it's usually the script.

But, sometimes it's just an actor you want to work with,

or a director you want to work with, or,

maybe even a cinematographer, you know.

Mmm-Hmm.

Maybe it's a whole variety of impulse, impulses, you know?

Do you think you could ever do just the writing,

and not the acting?

Well, I did.

I know, you've done it all. That's what I mean.

Did you feel like, at a certain point,

what made you get back into acting?

It's kind of a mystery to me that people find it

so confusing that you act and you write.

It's been done for centuries, you know.

Is it the same process for you, when you're writing

and when you're acting?

Basically? Same kind of...

Kind of...you know.

But because of the circumstances of each one.

One when you're sitting alone, normally, in a kitchen

or something, with a typewriter.

And the other one is you have to work with

a lot of other people.

And those circumstances change the way you get into it.

Mmm-Hmm. And how is it working on this one in particular?

Oh! Well, one thing nobody talks about, hardly,

is the budget was unbelievably low. Like, when we

were going into a gun fight scene,

they give you three cartridges, and they say,

Make sure you make each one of these count.

Because it's going to be a big gun fight,

but you only have three cartridges.

So, things like that.

Or, shooting bottles off the top of barrels,

and what you don't see is a girl standing at the

top of a ladder with a fishing pole with fishing line.

And she's popping each one of the bottles off

as you shoot.

Wow, you didn't feel that at all.

That kind of stuff, you know. Yeah, right.

So it's very much a handmade movie.

Do you still not fly?

No, I work a lot in Ireland, so...

You have to .

I have to.

Has it gotten easier?

Gotta get across the pond somehow.

Yeah. You don't want to be on the QE2?

Yeah (laughs).

Do you have another book in you, do you think?

Yeah, I'm working on a book now.

You are?

Mmm-Hmm.

Excellent.

Yeah, but, I'm determined to try to write some sustained

piece of prose instead of something that's all broken up.

Stories and stuff like that.

And, do you have to say no a lot?

Do people come after you for, I would imagine, you'd

be very much in demand.

It's like your presence, I feel like, improves

every movie.

Oh, thanks. No, I mean I try not to be in situations where

I'm being grabbed at, you know?

And, for the most part, you can avoid them, you know?

Not here, but elsewhere.

How do you avoid it?

You don't here.

You don't here.

No.

How is it here?

It's chaotic, crazy.

Everyone sees your hair and you're

immediately recognized.

Yeah, well, it's just growing out, actually,

from Cold in July.

Did you have another thing that you're working on?

Film-Wise?

Yeah.

I worked with Jeff Nichols on Mud, so I'm doing

his next movie.

Oh, you are?

Yeah.

Great. I look forward to that.

Yeah.

And this one, especially. Really fun,

great character.

Especially that ending, but I'm not gonna give it away.

Oh, the ending is great, isn't it?

It's great. It's great.

Something happened, but he doesn't know what it is.

(laughs)

Didn't Dylan write that? I think so.

You still friends with him?

Yeah. I rarely see him, but I'm still friends with him.

Do you see any of the people from that time?

Yeah.

So I guess it's kind of as cool as we imagined

to be Sam Shepard, as it is to be Sam Shepard.

(laughs)

Well, it's great to see you.

It's a personal treat for me.

Thanks.

It's great. I'm just such a fan of all your stuff.

Thank you very much.

I mean, I know you hear it all the time,

but I'm just gonna say it again.

Appreciate it.
